 Think as you may about me simply having nothing to say in the face of your reasoning, but as I've said I've lost the will and the energy to debate with people like you.
 
 Good day.

 
 No problem, hard to debate things like dictionary definitions and official body counts.
 
 If you have some more time later, I would like for you to take a look and see if you can find me a story that is obviously biased (and please no more where they simply used a literally correct term that you don't like).
 
 I am really interested in this. I have watched AJ for a few years now and have always found their stories to be factual and informative. i have always been a little confused by people who writye them off as "biased" apparently without any real reason. 
 
 You may note that an the US news channels, they will often show ground perspective footage with "courtesy Al-Jazeera" in the corner. This was always one of my favorite things about AJ. They ALWAYS have man on the ground coverage. Even when the coalition ordered them out of Iraq, their people stayed and were still providing on the ground coverage. 
 
 I personally also welcome it when they play tapes that the US stations won't play, like the Bin Laden tapes. Listening to the man gives you some interesting insights into his thought processes. You don't get this from a 2 second quote.
 
 I simply don't understand why some people insist on claiming that they are biased, despite the fact they cannot find a biased story to illustrate their point (and I am not just talking about, silent). 
 
 
 
Every news organization is biased... just to what side and what extent is the question.
 
 Obviously they'd be in a different leauge than, say, CNN or Fox.

 
 I'll give you this one. broker. Of course, watching other Arab language channels, I would definatly say that AJ is the Fox news of the Arab world, comparatively pro Bush, pro America, etc....
 
 I generally view AJ like I would MSNBC. Kind of middle of the road as opposed to being the communist news network or the republican parties pro0oganda network. 
 
 Of course, trusting just a single source for all your news is foolish in any case. Always shop around, compare stroies, and then think and decide who is telling you the truth. It helps if you can speak a few different languages (I woud suggest Arabic and Hebrew if you are interested in the ME, Japanese if you are interested in business, and French or German if you are interested in Europe. Russian is also good to have, but time consuming to learn.)/
